awd_titl_txt: A Longitudinal Study Predicting Postsecondary STEM Readiness Among Low-Income Minority Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This study continues a longitudinal study that began with students in preschool and will follow them into high school in a large, urban school district including a large number of African-American students and low-income students. The study is a unique opportunity to learn about how the students go through school from preschool through the end of high school. This opportunity will examine how their readiness for STEM careers and their beliefs about STEM. Their path through school will particularly focus on the connections to mathematics learning and achievement. This project will collect new data to make connections to data collected during the students elementary and middle school years. An important contribution to educational research, policy, and practice will be understanding math knowledge development and readiness for STEM careers over students' entire preK-12 experience. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

The project is designed to identify growth trajectories and predictors of more and less successful students. This work continues a study of approximately 500 low-income, predominantly African-American students who have been followed from preschool through 8th grade in a large urban school district. The goals are to (1) examine students' growth in math achievement across high school and related high school growth to previous patterns, (2) identify predictors of math achievement and other indicators of postsecondary readiness, and (3) describe low-income and minority students' beliefs about careers in STEM in high school, including how their beliefs have changed since middle school. The students are predominantly African American (80%) and over 90% eligible for free or reduced-price lunch. In each year of the study, the project team will conduct individual student assessments of math knowledge and collect administrative data on ACT math and science scores as well as course enrollment, grades and end-of-course exam scores, graduation rates, and students' intent to attend college after high school. During the fall of eleventh grade, focus groups with students will ask about their plans after high school and their beliefs about careers in STEM. Similar focus groups were conducted with the students in eighth grade.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project continued a longitudinal study that began with students in preschool and followed them through high school. Students were in a large, urban school district, including a large number of Black students and students from low-income households. The study was a unique opportunity to learn about the development of their readiness for STEM careers and their beliefs about STEM, particularly for mathematics. This project was supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

The project was designed to identify growth trajectories and predictors of more and less successful students. This work continued a study of approximately 500 low-income, predominantly Black students in a large, urban school district. The goals were to (1) examine students' growth in math achievement across high school and relate high school growth to previous growth patterns, (2) identify predictors of math achievement and other indicators of postsecondary readiness, and (3) describe these students' beliefs about careers in STEM in high school. In each year of the study, the project team conducted individual student assessments of math knowledge and collected administrative data including ACT math and science scores. During the fall of 11th grade, focus groups with students asked about their plans after high school and their beliefs about careers in STEM. 

This project has resulted in several findings with important implications for theory, practice, and policy. First, we identified four profiles of math motivation in our sample of students, including a profile of having high motivation across the constructs of expectancies of success, utility value of math, and interest in math. Black girls were less likely to be in the high motivational profile than Black boys, and a majority of students moved to a profile characterized by lower levels of motivation between 6th and 10th grade. Students in the high math motivational profile in 6th grade and those who maintained their motivation across the transition to high school had higher math test scores in 10th grade. We found that these math motivation profiles and transitions rarely predicted interest in having a STEM career in 10th grade. Also, we evaluated preschool and middle school predictors of mathematics ACT scores in our longitudinal sample. Students' math knowledge at age 4 predicted their math ACT score in 12th grade even after controlling for cognitive skills at age 4 and demographic characteristics. Two types of factors in middle school predicted students' math ACT scores - math knowledge (number, algebra, and geometry knowledge), and school placement (taking a high school math course in 8th grade). These two factors mediated the relation between math knowledge at age 4 and math ACT scores.  In contrast, executive function skill in 6th grade was not a unique predictor with math knowledge in the model. Findings were similar for predicting STEM ACT scores. These findings highlight the importance of considering multiple systems that influence students' mathematics development and for supporting college readiness.

We also found that students in our sample, who were from groups underrepresented in STEM, were missing the support they deserved to learn more about possible careers after high school and were most often relying on themselves to discover information about postsecondary options. The most support and exposure to colleges and careers came from their family, particularly for students at segregated schools. Despite the segregation of their schools and unequal division of experiencing encouraging math teachers in their classrooms depending on their math course level, students still believed that their biggest barrier to achieving their postsecondary goals was themselves and were blaming themselves if they failed. In addition, in examining the classroom experiences of students depending on whether they were enrolled in a general math course or advanced math course in 11th grade, we found that students in general math courses were more likely to have negative experiences when asking their math teachers questions in class. Students in general math courses also more frequently mentioned a lack of opportunities to work in small groups and receive help from peers compared to students in advanced classes. Groups of students in the advanced math courses more often mentioned positive experiences of having knowledgeable teachers and shared fewer negative comments related to how the teachers contributed to their success. Thus, in our sample of predominately Black students from low-income households, aspects of inclusive pedagogy were mostly experienced by students in advanced mathematics courses. Further work is needed to support schools in providing inclusive pedagogy to marginalized students in all levels of math courses. This project also provided important research opportunities for research assistants typically underrepresented in STEM, including presenting findings in lab meetings and conferences. Many of these students plan to continue on to future careers in STEM or STEM education. 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Kelley Durkin
